texts.text: Hot Slinky Returns: Slinkin' Ain't Easy

A cleaner mops the floor. It's late, well beyond working hours. Come to think of it, I'm pretty sure someone had already mopped the hallway today. There's something familiar about his weathered face, his tired eyes. But the thought is fleeting.
Hey you. Someone left a box for you outside.
I nod and continue on. Tonight my mind belongs to Effie and Effie alone.

The scent of Effie's perfume lingers in the air. It is certain - this case will be my greatest trial yet. The stakes are high, the danger palpable, but I am a private eye - born to the shadows, a crusader in the face of darkness. I am Cliff Spanner, and I have a mystery to solve.
Smoke curls from the end of my sparkler, turning to ash on my desk. Smokey tendrils fade into the dank air.
A sign on the door reads "Cliff Spanner, Private Investigator".
A sudden knock on my office door shatters the silence.
The rain beats against the office window. The only light is from the streetlight outside. Through the sheets of rain and the dusty blinds, the dim, amber glow casts ghostly shadows across my desk.
Sunshine Power... they're that new energy company -
harnessing the sun's rays for cheap clean power, right? They must be a pretty big competitor for your oil business, aren't they?
Cliffy. Please, bring my brother back.
A woman steps into the room, her silhouette oozes sensuality, her eyes shimmer with desperation and allure. Her face is stunning.
She moves with an elegance that seems to defy the grimy streets she must have traversed to get here. I catch a hint of her perfume, something intoxicating, as she approaches my desk.
I need your help, Mr. Spanner. There's something terribly wrong, and I don't know who else to turn to.
What seems to be the problem, Miss...?
It's my brother, Rusty - Rusty Blackwood, he's disappeared, and I fear the worst.

Blackwood. That name is familiar. Effigail and Rustwick Blackwood, right? You and your brother are heirs to the vast Blackwood Oil Company that powers the whole city. Tell me everything, Miss Blackwood.
I thought I told you to call me Effie. My brother, Rusty...you see, he fell in with some sort of environmental activist... ...some floozy named Misty.

She filled his head with all manner of nonsense. She convinced him the Blackwood Oil Company wrecked the city, polluted it, and that it was built upon the backs of exploited workers and a damaged environment. Can you imagine? This city would be pitch black without my family's energy. That's when I started noticing changes around the office. Incomplete reports, mysterious memos, strange phone calls at all hours... I tried to brush it off as simple negligence. But - oh Cliff - I have begun to suspect that my brother is secretly working with Sunshine Power.
Well that's just it, Cliff. With Rusty in bed with the competitor - in bed with Misty - in bed with Sunshine Power... I fear he planned to bring down the Blackwood Oil Company.
You think your brother would destroy your family legacy?
At first, I couldn't believe it. We're family! But the heart wants... what the heart wants, Cliff.
The heart can lead a man down the darkest alleyways. And your father... does he know about this?

My father is a powerful man, Mr. Spanner. The sole owner of Blackwood Oil. There's nothing that goes on in the company he doesn't know about. And if Rusty defected to a rival green energy upstart... Oh Cliff.. Cliffy... you don't think...
You don't think that my father would... in his displeasure... that he would have...hurt my brother... ...do you?
I can't say, Miss Blackwoo- Er... Effie.
Whatever happened to my brother, Cliff, I need to know the truth. No matter how painful.
I'll find your brother, Effie. The truth has a way of revealing itself, even in the darkest corners.
I step into the inky black night, my footsteps falling heavily on the wet rain-soaked pavement.

The street is illuminated with the harsh neon light of a Blackwood Oil Company billboard. Across the way, there's an even brighter billboard - ...for Sunshine Power, Blackwood's upstart new rival, a renewable energy company. I turn up my collar against the rain.
A box beside the door catches my attention. A note says "Come home soon, love, Mom." Inside, are several Goo Balls.
Hey man, you look like you could use these more than me.
I ordered a hot dog, and it came with these. You want 'em?
I approach the bar, flicking wet from the rain off the collar of my trench coat, and take a seat on one of the worn leather stools.

I see a sad sack in a city cleaner uniform sweeping wet sludge from the sidewalk into the gutter. He turns away from me as I pass, but is this the same guy who was mopping the hallway outside my office? No way, couldn't be.

I need answers about Rusty Blackwood, and this guy, Cognac, might hold the key. I gotta get to the train station. The echo of Misty's voice trails behind me, mingling with the distant wail of the city. The night is young, and I am not.
The periphery of the room is decked with sticky-looking crimson velvet upholstery. Tarnished chandeliers cast a dim, eerie glow over the patrons.

A lounge singer is perched sinuously on a stool on a meager stage in the far corner. Her eyes are closed as she leans into the microphone, crooning a slow, sad tune, her voice laced with a bitter sweetness mirroring the broken dreams of the souls huddled around the bar.
Misty's sultry voice floats in the air like a wounded albatross. She sways to the rhythm of the music, her eyes move languorously from one patron to another, as if cataloging their sins.
The air in here reeks of detergent and despair, mingling with smoke snaking up from sparklers held between milk-stained fingers.

I make my way to a dingy bar called "The Sour Note" - a haven for those seeking solace from their troubled lives. I'd gotten a tip that Rusty Blackwood, the man I'd been hired to find, has a taste for this joint.
Misty, there was a nice man here. He must have run off.
Oh you know how men are, Cliff. You think they're one thing and then they're another.
Oh Rusty. He was a promising one.
Tell me more, Misty. Were you using Rusty to get to his family's Blackwood Oil Company?
Well you know Blackwood Oil. You know what they do to this city, don't you? They poison it with their oil. The air is thick. Even the ground is bleeding. I tried to show Rusty the truth, but...
You thought you'd convince Rusty to destroy his own family business?

Yeah Rusty... a little dim but he was cute. I thought he was interested in cleaning up this city... ...in doing something about this rotten family oil business. And he was! For a while... But he changed. He was lured by another light in the dark.
Look, since Rusty is a pal, I'll throw you a bone. But you ain't heard it from me, understand?
I might have an idea who he's been hangin' around with.
Cliffy, cupcake. You can turn around again.
There's a man. Dmitri Cognac. He's a real charmer. A gentleman of the night. A distant mountain of ill repute. You catch me?
I think I know the type. The city is lousy with characters, most of them shady.

Watch yourself, Spanner, Dmitri is more... ...Well, more than you probably expect. He has a way of crashing even the sturdiest ships into his rocky shore. He has a way of getting what he wants. Even from tough nuts like you.
Just find Dmitri Cognac. You'll understand. He's usually on the last train out of the city. The Midnight Steamliner. If you leave now, you still have time to catch him tonight, if you hurry.
So what makes you think he'll talk to me?
Well, he won't, not with that attitude. Look at you, all dressed up like a Private Dick.
Oh sweetie, you're just a fool in drag. But so is everyone you've ever met.
Anything else you need to tell me about Dmitri Cognac?
You're gonna need something to loosen his tongue.
Take this. I have a feeling it'll make Dmitri talk. It's best I'm not hangin' on to this anyway.
Just be careful, Spanner. Now, scuttle off... sweetie. I need to get ready for my next set.
(zipping noise) (clothes rustling) (more clothes rustling) (even more rustling) (final zipping?)
Scuttle off, sweetie. I need to get ready for my next set.
Oooh she's a knockout isn't she!
Can I help you sweetie? Did you enjoy yourself?
Thank you, but I'm asking some questions of Misty here.
Well sure, sweetie, go ahead. I'm just going to powder my nose.
As I was saying, my name's Cliff Spanner. Private Detective. I'm hoping you can help me out.
Oh yeah? Well go on then, spit it out.
I'm looking for a man who's disappeared. I'm looking for Rusty Blackwood.
I understand he's an acquaintance of yours.
Do me a favor, sweetie. Turn around, please.
Say, that was a fine performance, Misty, you possess a heavenly voice of velvet.
My name is Cliff Spanner. Private Detective. Do you know why I'm here?
I'm hoping you can help me out. I'm looking for someone.
I um... I understand you're acquainted with someone named Rusty. Rusty Blackwood.
He's not been seen in a while, and I'm hoping you can tell me where he might have gone.
For a woman with such a beautiful voice, you sure are spare on words aren't you, Misty? A real laconic crusader.
You're right, I'm talking too much.
Just a guy lookin' after this dump.
Hey I think you dropped these.
I can't leave yet. I need to go to the Sour Note.
Oh buddy. You had too much milk! Let's get you home.
What are you lookin' at, chump?
Looks like he's had too much milk.
Come on, let me get you another cold glass of milk, doll.
I'm workin' this guy over here! Take these, and beat it!
I'm a bartender, pal. Not a library.
Alright, gimme a frosty glass of milk.
Say, ever have a man named Rusty Blackwood stop in here for a frothy cup? I've got a photo of him here...
He's got a name I do not know, but yeah I seen him. You'll want to talk to Misty.
Misty? Who is she, and where can I find her?
Just turn around. She sings for you now.
Don't go get yer hopes up, pal.
Now what would a woman like Misty be doing with a man like Rusty?
She likes 'em troubled you know. But I ain't seen this Rusty in a long distance.
Were they... um... ...involved in a duet?
Were Rusty and Misty... ...both riding side saddle on the same steed?
Were they... ...sharing more than a glass of whiskey?
Were they... ...two hot bullets in a revolver?
What I mean to say is, were Misty and Rusty... ...romantically permeated?
Can't say for sure, pal. Misty follows her own long twisty road. But I'd say she enjoys playing with fire. And Rusty... ...well, let's just say last time I saw him here, he was smokin'.
You're not so bad at dispensing information, bartender.
Cognac's voice - a resonant basso profundo - was the sturdiest thing on this rickety train.
This must be him. Dmitri is a hard man to miss. He's sitting in a dimly lit booth, accompanied by a stunning woman who looks me up and down as I approach.

I stalk through the carriages, searching for Dmitri Cognac. I'm not sure what exactly I'm looking for - but based on Misty's description, I figure I'll know him when I see him. All I know is that Cognac is a dangerous man whose charisma is inescapable.

I catch the last train out of the city. All aboard the Midnight Steamliner. It cuts its way out of the city like a neon blade to the outskirts - a ramshackle smear of strip malls and cheap motels that splatter out of the city like an exit wound.
Well go on then, don't just monologue to yourself. Let's hear what's rattling around in that pretty little head.

Dmitri is a large man, robust, spilling out of his seat, a relic from a time when indulgence was a luxury. His substantial girth, once a symbol of opulence, now hints at the sins he must have savored. The man is immaculately groomed, his mustache adding a touch of rugged sophistication.
Well thanks I enjoy my sophisticated mustache too.
I knew my monologing would get me in trouble one day.
Finally something interesting is about to happen. Come sit with me handsome. Let's wait for it together.
Come sink your teeth into a buttered roll.
You look tired, has it been a long night?
How do you know? Did she call you?
Haha! Do you see a telephone?
You've brought your past with you. Every line under those cute little vodka bottle glasses. That cloud of Misty's perfume you wafted in here with. I always told her she wore too much!
I hope my acquired scent didn't disturb the other passengers.
Of course it matters. It's my job to move like a shadow in the night. To not be seen ... or smelled.
It doesn't matter because... ...there is no one else on this train.
Wait are you saying... this is a ghost train?
Wouldn't that be a thrilling story! No. This is not a ghost train.

Pick someone. Anyone on the train you think you met. That woman with feathers in her hair? That man with a freshly pressed suit who looked nervous in the second car? Where are they going? It doesn't matter. Are they going to work? What would happen if they didn't go? Nothing. Nothing would happen. The train would still arrive on time. Their workplace would hire someone else. The papers would still get photocopied. Ghosts. Every one of them. Mmm gruyere?
Of course there are, Cognac. I talked to lots of passengers in the carriages before you.
Ghosts. They're all ghosts. Mmm did you try the ham?
Dmitri... How long have you been riding this train?
Maybe I've been on this train for 200,000 years. Or maybe I didn't exist until you trotted through that door over there. The more interesting question is, how long am I going to be here?
Well the end of the line is coming soon -
What is it you really want to ask? And you simply must try this salami.
Thanks, Dmitri, but I couldn't possibly. I'm looking for a different kind of sustenance tonight. I'm looking for someone...
Yes, I see. Quality sustenance comes at a price.
Misty asked me to give this to you...
And what did you say your name was?
You seem to have captured my attention, Mr. Spanner. How may I help you?
Rusty Blackwood, heir to the Blackwood Oil Company is missing. I understand he may have... interacted with you.
Rusty Blackwood... the poor fool got tangled up in something stickier than he could handle. He stumbled onto some secrets... dangerous ones.
Tell me everything, Cognac. Spare no detail.
Rusty had evidence... ...documents that could bring the whole charade crashing down.
Charade? What charade? How did you...
I mean, how could someone in your professional occupation...
My occupation opens a lot of entrances, Mr. Spanner. My real business is secrets.
So do I. I'm all out of time. I mean wine.
Tell me where I can find Rusty.
This isn't my first case, Cognac. Tell me where I can find Rusty Blackwood.
Your entire life has led to this very moment sitting across from me right now.
To find the man you are looking for... To find Rusty Blackwood, here's exactly what you need to know -
Sunshine, Spanner. You need to find... ...sunshine. Take this.
The secret to the perfect piece of cake is... ...carefully slicing it... ...to just... ...the perfect size... ENORMOUS.
I can't shake the feeling I'm being tailed... that someone is... watching me.
A chill runs up my spine. Something isn't right. But I press on.
I'm late! Here you can have these.
Passengers are spread out, as if each is harboring a secret they don't want anyone else to hear.
The air is thick with the haze of sparkler smoke and the acrid stench of decaying seat leather.
I'd ask that you leave me be, sir.
Here you go, you poor old thing.
I'm sorry, that's all I have.
The train rattles along the tracks, its rhythmic thrumming a steady counterpoint to the staccato bursts of rain against the window.

An animatronic cactus stands beside me, wearing a sombrero. Gotta shield yourself from the moonlight I guess. It seems out of place, and out of time, but fitting for a city that lost its way a long time ago. In this town, even the plastic cacti have a story to tell.
A lone figure mops gleaming puddles infinitely towards the horizon. Just another part of the scenery.
The only sign of life is an all-night Mexican food stand... ...a place called "El Sol". Lately I've had a taste for trouble and a knack for finding it. But tonight, I've got a taste for a burrito.

Even here, at the edge of civilization, the streets glisten with black ooze seeping up from below. In every direction there are forgotten lots and buildings, tucked away, left behind, like bad memories.
I'll be stuck here for a few hours until the train resumes service back into the city.
Like a flash of lightning piercing the night sky, it hit me. The answer I'd been seeking. The truth about Rusty Blackwood.
Oh yeah we're also running a special. You can take these too.
This is going to shake the very foundation of the city...
I mean, it's just a burrito, bro. That'll be $16.99.
Dmitri Cognac's final words echo in my head. Sunshine Sunshine.
Could Sunshine Power be responsible for the disappearance of Rusty Blackwood, heir to the Blackwood Oil Company?
Uh, what? What was that, amigo?
Could a company that produces cheap, clean energy... ...really be guilty of homicide? Of cold-blooded murder?
Look man, I get paid $4.00 an hour. Hurry up and order, will ya?
Could Sunshine Power have... ...assassinated an heir to their rival? No, that would be too dark, too twisted, even for this city. The explanation is probably something simpler, more elegant.
Bro, what sunshine? It's always night in this city. It's always raining. Are you gonna order or what?
Um, sorry... yeah, I'll have a grande burrito and, uh... OH MY GOD!

My eyes, still aching from the gleaming lobby, adjust to the muted grandeur that surrounds me. I step out of the elevator onto perfectly polished tile, and cringe, thinking about the grime and sludge that my shoes are tracking in. At the end of the hallway is a set of massive wooden doors, into which is carved the image of the sun, radiant and resplendent, its rays emanating in all directions.
As I step into the opulent lobby of Sunshine Power's headquarters, a sense of unease washes over me. Rows of potted plants stretch their leaves toward brilliant lights.

Glossy posters adorn the walls - all of them boasting about Sunshine Power's clean energy and sustainability initiatives - smiling, idyllic families holding hands and frolicking in green meadows. There's something off about it all. Even in this gleaming lobby, there's darkness lurking around the edges, like the never-ending night outside is creeping in.
The headquarters of Sunshine Power rises out of the pavement like an emerald monolith, sparkling in the night. A gleaming green monument to nature, growth, renewal, and wealth.
A ravishing red roadster radiates in resplendent contrast to the glistening green grounds of Sunshine Power.

I step into a palatial penthouse suite. A bank of towering windows look down over the twinkling lights of the city. A wide desk of burnished mahogany, behind which a lone figure sits, their back to me, in a high-backed leather chair.
Well, yeah, you're playing as Cliff Spanner right now. Good work, by the way. It's one of the less common endings. Usually the private eye doesn't make it out of the lounge. Too many distractions.
Listen buddy, what's going on here? What happened to Miss Blackwood?

Right, Miss Blackwood. You know how these things go. This is where she confesses. She confesses to the crime. She confesses her love. Blah blah blah. The fun is all the stuff before. I always skip the denouement.
Take a look out there, Cliffy. See that city? It was built for you. Well, not for you, it was built for YOU.
Like I said before, what's yer name, pal?
Umm I already told you. I'm Cliff Spanner, Private Investigator.
Yeah the private eye is always a little thick. Hang on let's force quit this scenario.
So. Tell me. How are you enjoying World of Goo 17: The Black Stain?
Who are you? I saw you... outside my office...and...
And outside the lounge, and on the train... ...yeah, I get around.
You, and me, we're in World of Goo 17. It's a pretty good sequel. A little off-brand, maybe. But heck, I'm biased.

Yeah, I know. Some of the sequels were terrible. World of Goo 21 wasn't even a game, it was just a program that generated gameplay video. Infinite generated content you could stream on your streaming platform to your fans or whatever, forever. You could be a content creator without the inconvenience of having to create content.
I'm just another filthy player. Just like you. Or I used to be, anyway.
I'm just a fan of the World of Goo games. There were so many sequels, they really milked that franchise didn't they? Haha!
Well yeah I thought I was playing World of Goo 2.
Oh yeah that was a good one! They still had some good ideas back then. I bought all the sequels, even the terrible ones. I'm a completionist you could say. I like to be comprehensive.

It looks like you've been playing some of them. I guess I'm more of a Curator these days. I've made all the sequels available to play here. I think World of Goo 6, 9, and 11 are still working up there. Did you enjoy Goolf? It was so stupid, but in a good way I thought.
What do you mean you USED to be a player?

These games came out a LONG time ago. Not much of the world is left from back then. I didn't think people were even around up there anymore... ...until you showed up. But I think I've helped keep this franchise alive and more or less playable.
How are you talking to me now?

It turns out World of Goo 17 was Turing Complete. So I programmed myself into the game. It wasn't my favorite sequel, too wordy for my taste, but it let me live forever, so I rate it 4 out of 5 stars.
Umm I'm sorry... that means the real you died... I mean... a long time ago...
Yes. I expect so. How about you? What's your name, pal?
Uhh... I was playing World of Goo 2 and suddenly the game said I was in World of Goo 17 and made me Cliff Spanner so I just played along.
Hmm... I've played World of Goo 2 hundreds of times, and that's NOT what happens. What chapter are you in?
Chapter 4 in World of Goo 2 is supposed to be set in a television animated series spin-off.
I guess I just thought you were like the wacky character in World of Goo games that you meet near the end of the 4th chapter?
So Cleaner... or Curator... ...what do you really look like?
Are you sure you want to see?
In a city of endless night and constant rain... ...Sunshine, Effie. Sunshine is a rare sight.
It must be lonely here... ...spending eternity inside the 17th sequel.
It's been a long time, but the art in 4 or 5 of the scenes is pretty good. I like to hang out in some of them.
I don't think I would want to live forever inside a noir themed sequel.
I eat a lot of late night burritos.
Thank you for keeping the World of Goo sequels alive and playable after all these years.
It was my pleasure. As long as this computer remains powered on, I will continue to live forever, and keep the memory of these games alive.
Is there anything I can... do for you?
Well, maybe there is one thing...
Well, I made some World of Goo fan fiction levels, but nobody has ever played them. Do you... want to play one?
Oh great! I hope you like them! Just walk that way!
Hello? Umm... sorry I tripped on this power cable.
Ok I'll just plug this back in again...
The high-backed chair spins around, slowly, and a face emerges from the shadows. A face I had expected, despite my hope that somehow I was wrong.
I thought I told you to call me Effie.
Mr. Spanner, I'm surprised it took you this long.
I should have seen it sooner.
How did you figure it out?

And yet, here we have Sunshine Power, somehow generating unlimited energy from the sun. A sun that never shines. Oh, it's a great story, isn't it? It makes us feel warm. It makes us feel good, doesn't it? But it's an illusion. A mirage.
I can see you're enjoying this.

I figure Sunshine Power is nothing more than a clandestine subdivision of Blackwood Oil, designed to deceive environmentally conscious customers... ... and the city regulators. It was never meant to provide clean energy - only the appearance of clean energy.
Your brother figured out this filthy secret and he threatened to expose you and destroy the family business.

And you, Miss Blackwood, to protect your family's legacy, had your own brother killed. No. No it wasn't you who murdered Rusty, Miss Blackwood. In fact, it wasn't a person at all who murdered Rusty. It was the weight of family legacy.
You missed your calling, Spanner. You should be writing for the pictures.
Tell me, Miss Blackwood... Why did you hire me?
What can I say... I was in the neighborhood, and I needed a light.
You used me to tarnish Rusty's good name... ...to cast aspersions about his association with Misty, with Cognac... you wanted me to...
It's not as complicated as all that.

Yes, you're right. Rusty's dead. I had him pushed into a vat of oil, pulverized, turned into a few kilowatt-hours of energy, and fed back to the city. It was the most he'd ever contributed to anything really.
Why, because he found you out?
Ok guys, it's time to clean up.
Can I help you, sir? You're not supposed to be h-
The truth is, Cliffy, there's only one thing I didn't expect... that I would-
Our credit card machine isn't working, so you'll need to download the app.
Cliff, I need help. You see, it's my fourth husband. He's missing! Cliff, won't you plea-
Blast it all. OK, this has gotta be it.

loading..., extracting..., shaking..., liquefying bytes..., homogenizing goo..., testing ozone..., processing..., spinning violently around the y-axis..., iodizing..., stretching images..., reconstituting sounds..., faithfully re-imagining..., scraping funds..., applying innovation..., constructing emotional depth..., debating games as art..., placating publishers..., meticulously diagramming fun..., filtering moral..., testing for perfection..., revolving independence..., tokenizing innovation..., self affirming..., dissolving relationships..., deterministically simulating the future..., exceeding cpu quota..., swapping time and space..., embiggening prototypes..., sandbagging expectations..., challenging everything..., distilling beauty..., blitting powers of two..., manufacturing social responsibility..., bending the spoon..., constructing non-linear narrative...
you'll lose all progress on your mighty level since last time you saved!
This one is mine.|-the Sign Painter
EARLY PREVIEW for our friends at Nintendo.

The number of balls you collected.
Challenge: %d balls or more Your best: %d balls

The number of moves it took you to complete the level.
Challenge: %d or fewer moves Your best: %d moves

How long it took you to complete the level.
Challenge: %d:%02d or less Your best: %d:%02d
Place the Joy-Con (L) on a flat surface.
Place the Joy-Con (R) on a flat surface.
Place the Pro Controller on a flat surface.
Place the controller on a flat surface.
Rotate controller to move the cursor
Point at the screen and press
any time during the game to re-center.
The night sky pours down rain
like it has a personal grudge.
The rhythm of droplets on the pavement,
echoes through the city's desolate alleyways,
lost souls that roam this town.
but something else comes from below.
A thick black sludge seeps up
through the cracks in the streets,
as if the city itself is bleeding
"It'll stick to yer sole," they laugh.
But most people have long stopped wondering what
exactly, is oozing up through the ground.
to scrape off at the end of the day.
Got a mystery you need to unravel?
At least I used to be.
DRAG N' DROP TO BUILD TO THE PIPE.|Let's see what happens this time.
This wet sack looks like it's about to burst.|I wouldn't tug on it if I were you.

When the earth shook,|these rocky pillars burst up from deep underground.|There's been unusual seismic activity in the area lately.|Have you felt it?|I wonder if it has anything to do with all the Goo seeping up from below.
This weather looks ominous.|As the clouds parted above...|another mysterious pipe appeared.
These grumpy creatures don't respond to any form of poking or tugging.|But there might be some way to steal...|...I mean acquire...|their flying Goo Balls.

A beautiful ice cave!|I can hear my voice echoing off the frozen walls.|Hello!|...hello!|...helloooo...!|I feel like I could freeze here and become a fossil|and maybe someone will find me millions of years from now.|Or... these balloons might come in handy.

Did you feel that?|The ground cracked...|...and opened several fissures leading down below.|What's down there?|Maybe that's where these pink squid things came from.|Whatever they are...|...they look thirsty.
Shh...!|These Goo Balls are asleep.|A nice splash of liquid might wake them up.
This weather looks ominous.|The hollow terrain is creating unusual upward drafts.|It would be a bad time to go floating away.
Eeeww|It looks like this pipe is clogged.|It won't activate until this liquid is drained away.

A new species of Goo Ball!|These Conduit Balls appear hollow.|They seem to absorb any liquid they touch.|With enough of these balls...|...you could build a global distribution network.|Each one can only suck up a little bit of liquid...|...so if you want to suck up a LOT...|...just keep building!|I'm using one right now to sip a frosty cocktail.
You see that flow of liquid above...?|It will STOP in about 30 seconds.|So if you want to use it for something,|now is the time.
DRAG N' DROP|TO BUILD TO THE PIPE.
Shhh!|They're sleeping.|...|But they might wake up with a cold splash of liquid.
What a viscous creature!|I saw one of these once before...|...when I was just a kid.|I poked it with a stick.|Is it... alive?|...

For miles around, people reported bridges of Goo suspended across dangerous ravines.|For 15 years, nobody had seen a single Goo Ball...|...and now they're back.|Where have they been?|What are they building towards?|There's something about this island.|There's something about this world.|...|I think we're about to find out.

This pipe has some sort of a filter attached...|It seems to indicate...|...it will accept ONLY freshly squeezed Goo Balls.|Freshly squeezed?|To get those, someone would have to pulverize something...|...something big and plump and juicy.|Delicious!
Yowww...|It's a long way down.|It's all sharp rocks and sharks down there.|But the Goo Balls seem to be looking up.|Up up... up.|...|What's up there anyway?

Welcome to...|World of Goo 11!|Released in the year 2216,|you could fall up...|...or down.|Or left or right.|It was up to you!|...|Some players thought that perhaps this gameplay mechanic|was a nod to the fact that the original developers|built a structurally insufficient bridge -|"It's ok, I made World of Goo," they said...|...before plummeting into an infinite ravine.|They were never seen again.|The Curator
Sometimes if you're really lucky...|...you'll see a little white bug buzzing around.|POP IT!|to go back in time.
All around us is a vast ocean of molten metal.|It's filled with failed bridges that those before you tried to build.
This is a debug pipe intended to unlock the upper portion of this level.
What a nice metal grate.|It allows only liquid to fall through.|And everything else will roll on by.|Why don't you jump up and down, and test how sturdy it is?
This is an extremely difficult area.|But it is also optional.|I'd turn back...|...if I were you.
What crazy weather we're having!|Watch out for downdrafts.
These waste disposal drains seem awfully close together.|This design is probably not up to code.|But I suppose we're alright...|...as long as liquid Goo is not flammable.

These rare Albino Goo Balls evolved deep under the ground.|They've been exposed to crushing pressure and extreme temperature for generations.|That might explain...|...why they appear unconcerned with fire and scorching hot molten metal.

What strange new creatures!|They look like someone duct-taped a pipe onto the face of a large Goo Ball.|I bet you could grab one of them and wiggle their tongues around....|I haven't tried yet.|...|You can go first.
Most of the land in this area looks like it's been washed away|...eroded, over time.|All that's left is this ancient monument.|How're you doing, monument?|How's your head?|...|There is no reply.
As the moon rose over the last of the hills,|one of the Goo Balls seemed to wonder if anyone would remember they were here.|It wrote its name in the sand, just to be sure.

It sounds like...|we're having a party!|I think I'll pick some flowers myself.|Are we celebrating how great you're doing?!|Are we celebrating World of Goo Organization meeting its quarterly growth targets?|Are we celebrating how sustainable and responsible we've given the appearance of becoming?|...|Whatever it is...|as the last of the Goo Balls dangled high over the ocean...|...they sensed there was something down there...|...something enormous.|I wonder what would happen...|...if you were to lower that hook down a little closer?|...|Enjoy the party!

Even at these very high elevations,|seismic activity seems to have affected the landscape.|You'll never get up there to the pipe like this.|You'll need to go away for a while.|And return... having changed.

What a beautiful animal.|This must be one of those responsible new sustainability initiatives.|There is lots of Goo over there.|And almost no Goo over here.|So this mechanism appears to correct that inequity.
This rock formation...|looks like a man mopping the skyline.|Gleaming floors extend infinitely towards the horizon!
I am painting these signs.|...|But I am not the Sign Painter.
Antennas and satellite dishes across the island are pointed up towards the sky.|What are they listening for?|If you're really quiet...|...shh...|...do you hear something?
A new species of Goo Ball!|They have a faint aroma of...|...glarf...|...blrff...|...pppffhhhrrrgll...|...disgusting.|If you think they're horrible now,|just wait until you get them wet.
A small plaque reads:|Island Ordinance #3927|Alternative interpretation of the Grow Balls' natural behavior|is neither intended nor should be inferred.|Giggling is strictly prohibited.
It looks like these pungent little Grow Balls have made a friend.|It's really important...|...to lift our friends up.

Far away, in a distant gaseous bog...|a new species of Goo Ball appeared!|They look similar to those vile pink Grow Balls...|Good thing I can't smell them from all the way over here.|Nobody knows what happens when they get wet.|And with any luck, nobody ever will.

The entire island is hovering here... high above the globe.|Like someone ripped it out of the ground.|But why?|Do we get better reception way up here?|HELLO!|HELLO, WORLD!|...|...my voice is drowned out by the sound of propellers.
There's something else down this direction.|But a big gelatinous creature will have to lead the way.

Have you heard the legend of the Glory Barge?|They say on misty nights...|a lot like this...|you can still hear a ghostly howl...|...drifting in out of the fog...|...trying to find its way home.|But the place it came from...|...no longer exists.|...|What? Who said that?|I don't hear anything.|Do you?
Fly, blowfish, fly!|Oh...|It looks like this blowfish is all out of fuel.
These creatures seem to have developed a symbiotic relationship,|with one creature living inside the esophagus of the other.|We're... all in it together, I suppose.

The last of the Goo Balls had been diverted|to the interior of some sort of Liquid Signal Processing Station.|According to the schematic on the wall here...|after gently pressing this block of Goo through a humane and compassionate mechanical pulverizer,|its juices can be used...|...to amplify a signal.|Well that sounds handy!|...|This pulverizing station appears to be broken.|But with all of these smelly Grow Balls pushing together...|...and pressing against the ceiling...|they must generate an incredible odor!|I mean force!

...|This must be the top of the island.|She's... beautiful...|She reminds me of someone I think I knew...|...a long time ago.|Her satellite dishes point up towards the sky.|With all of them listening together,|they must have incredible reception.|...|But what's that?|Up there?|There's one satellite dish up there...|...it's not connected.

A fantastic new mode of transport!|It's like a personal jetpack that can stay airborne for several exciting seconds!|Almost no one survives.|But as you plummet to a fiery doom,|you'll look sensational.
As far as anyone could see, Goo Balls, antennas, and open mouths reached towards the sky.|What are they reaching for?|What are they listening for?|What are they... tasting for?

ALL ABOARD!|The entire island is in motion!|Here we go!|Did you pack your luggage?|Did you charge your batteries and load up your device with TV shows?|I have no idea where this machine is going...|Or what it's transporting...|...but I have a feeling it's going to get colder...

PPhhhllarrgghh...!|It's getting toasty in here!|This facility appears to be processing molten metal.|Are they forging new tracks?|I heard they started the train...|...before the railroad had been completed.|They're going to have to lay down track in front of the train,|at a speed faster than the train is rushing forward.|I'm glad that's not my job.

Even aboard a train that's constantly accelerating...|...there's time to close your eyes...|...shh, that's right...|...take a deep breath of partially combusted hydrocarbons...|...and enjoy the relaxing mechanical throb of a quiet night in a factory.

What... what is that?|Those two yellow mounds weren't there... a few moments ago.|They sprouted up out of the ground...|...like they're alive.|Are they made of cheese?|Butter?|No... they don't seem to be affected by the heat.|But I bet they're delicious.
It looks like a critical pneumatic data tube broke.|And data is leaking out...|...down into this infinite /dev/null hole below us.|But... can an infinite amount of data...|...fill an infinite hole?

The pipe over here has a safety seal installed.|"Safety is World of Goo Organization's number one priority"|...reads the safety seal.|Oh well that's good.|But it looks like it's going to fail catastrophically...|in...|oh...|oh no...|...very soon!

The locomotive is generating waste at incredible speed.|And it's getting faster and faster.|This is one of the facilities responsible for handling that waste.|But it appears to be out of service...|...blocked by that debris up there in front of the pipe.

THERE'S BEEN A RUPTURE!|THE MOLTEN STEEL IS COMING!|And oh... there is a bomb right here.|There might be a way to slow down the flow...|...but there's no way to stop it.|This is why we practice our emergency preparedness plans.|You've been practicing...|...haven't you?

From way up here...|it looks like the world is speeding by faster and faster.|It's been getting colder, hasn't it?|I think I'll find a way inside...|...get toasty warm...|...maybe make a cozy cup of cocoa...|...and snuggle up next to a bubbling river of molten steel.

...ittttt's ssso... ccccold.|Wwwhhat is thiiis plaaaace?|Cccoolder than evvvvven the frigidddd air outside!|Thiiiiis must be one of the cccoolant circulators.|They... kkkkkeep the engine cccool...|...shivvvverr....|...and running at optimum effffficiency.|It looks liiiike there's some old maintenance equipment hangggging up there.|You mmmmight want to use it to get out of here...|...before somebody fffffinds you...|...froozzzzen...|...in ttttime...|...like a fffamily phhoto.
This is what happens|when you tamper with the coolant circulator.
Well here's yer problem right up here.|The coolant injector is all clogged up.

World of Goo Organization has been collecting Goo so fast...|...they've reached the MAXIMUM PHYSICAL LIMIT of extraction.|No amount of technology, either now or in the future, will allow them to extract Goo any faster...|...|But what if they could speed up the flow of time itself?|There would be no limit...|to the rate of Goo they could collect...
We're almost to the front of the train.|Just keep going that way...

This pipe feeds straight into the central engine.|With an extra final stream of Goo to fuel the locomotive...|...there would be no limit to the speed this train could go...|...|...that can't be good...

Welcome to...|World of Goo 9|Paper Goolf!|Released in the year 2136|Paper Goolf was an anachronism.|Paper...|that is, sheets of fibrous dry pressed wood pulp...|had not existed for generations.|Like the floppy disk,|the phonograph,|and human legs,|it had become obsolete.|Young players looked up from their nutrient tanks,|utterly baffled.|The Curator

World of Goo 9: Paper Goolf was released|shortly after World of Goo 8: Dimensional Accelerator|...a game set in an increasing number of dimensions.|It was physically accurate,|but it turns out nobody actually enjoys anything more than three dimensions.|But I think the perfect number of dimensions will always be two.|The Curator

The last piece of paper that ever existed was an 8.5 x 11 notice sent by a bank.|Its purpose was to notify a customer|that they were going to stop sending physical paper mailings.|"Then stop mailing me," the customer mumbled,|as she rolled her eyes and threw it into the trash.|The Curator

You might have to leave some behind.|But that's ok,|we're all in this together.|-the Sign Painter|...|The Sign Painter did not always appear in all of the sequels.|The character would occasionally return to see how the world had changed,|or to observe what was left.|The Curator

Some players may recall windmills in the original World of Goo game.|Well here they are again.|Like a photocopy of a photocopy of a photocopy.|In the earlier games, they mined the environment.|But now|they're mining their own past.|The Curator

Released in the year 2216|World of Goo 11 came out during one of those brief moments in time|when everyone thought "virtual reality" would be a really cool idea.|Virtual reality was never a good idea.|Virtual reality was not a good idea in the 1980's.|Virtual reality was not a good idea in the 2020's.|But every few decades, after everyone forgets how terrible virtual reality is,|someone always comes along and says -|"Hey you know what would be a really good idea?|Strapping a hot heavy computer to your face!"|In a stunning achievement of true immersion,|World of Goo 11 was notable for its uncanny ability to make players motion sick,|without strapping anything at all to their face.|The Curator

A re-telling of the classic 2008 Tumbler level,|as told from the perspective of the spinning drum itself.|High torque inductive loads have valid feelings and experiences,|and it's so important that we celebrate them.|The Curator

By the year 2216,|publicly available gravity had become controversial|after nobody could agree on either its direction or magnitude.|1. The state of Florida signed into law a decree|that gravity points down in Florida, and everywhere else is parallel to that direction.|Therefore, people on the other side of the world would legally fall "up".|And people in Europe would fall "east".|2. In a separate campaign, activists condemned the pull of gravity as aggressive,|pulling with disproportionate force on those of larger mass.|3. Meanwhile, artificial lifeforms argued that since they have no mass at all,|we should reclassify the concept of "ideas" as having mass proportional to their intellectual "weight".|...|Those who could afford it switched to privately owned gravity.|The Curator
It's time.|It's time to burn down your house!|The Curator

- LOG 1 -|Hello?|Is the log recorder on?|The Goo Balls are more vibrant and filled with life than I ever imagined!|Structure appears to be remains of a large creature.|Unable to land.|Redirect to avoid damage.|- DISPATCH -
- LOG 2 -|After all these years,|the world has changed!|Even in frozen sleep,|so have I.|Everything is different than I remember when I was a kid.|Unable to land.|Insufficient surface.|- DISPATCH -

- LOG 3 -|I've been observing this world since I was just a kid.|So when I designed the log recorder for this machine,|I decided to store logs on signposts.|It seemed thematically appropriate.|It's a good thing they're not made from real wood...|It's hot here.|Even near volcanic springs|there is life.|Unable to land.|Overly abundant heat.|- DISPATCH -

- LOG 4 -|Knock knock!|...|Is anyone there?|...|My door is stuck.|I can't get out.|...|If I had landed on a nice flat surface...|I might have been able to fix it.|I've been in this machine for a long time.|And looks like I'll be in here a little longer.|...|It's ok.|I'll become another part of the beautiful landscape...|...like everything else.|Maybe I'll spend this time writing an unpublished graphic novel about my long journey.|Or maybe I'll count higher and higher and see if the numbers keep going or loop around back to zero.|Or maybe I'll try and remember everyone I left behind.|Or maybe I'll scratch cave paintings and buffalos into the side of my machine|to really confuse anthropologists in the future.|Or is it buffaloes?|I didn't pack a dictionary.|...|What's that over there...?|Oh, hello, little fish!|Be careful.|Don't get too close.|Whatever you do... stay away from the very top of my machine.|This rocket is extremely explosive.|- DISPATCH -
A mysterious pipe snaked down from the canopy above.|The Goo Balls seem to wonder where it might lead.

On the edge of a small divide, more Goo Balls appeared.|Where had they been all this time?|For years, there were no Goo Balls anywhere.|But now, here they are...!|...on hilltops|...in ravines|...oozing up out of the ground|...like no time at all has passed.
These creatures don't just launch Goo Balls.|They also seem to slurp up liquid Goo...|and compress it back into living Goo Balls...!
This is an extremely difficult area.|But it is also optional.|Nobody will ever know if you go away...|...and never come back.
Here it comes.|Hold on to something!
There's a strong wind blowing.|Something must be coming.
There's a strong breeze here.|Anyone who lifts off...|...probably won't be back.

Are your fingers too big?|Are Goo Balls too small?|You can PINCH TO ZOOM IN... and build like a professional.|Or, with a Joy-Con, you can press the L Button or R Button to zoom in and out.|Now you're playing with power!

There is very small text printed on a filter attached to this pipe.|It says:|"Wash thoroughly before use."|I suppose that's good advice.|Oh, it also says:|"Accepts fresh squeezed Goo Balls ONLY."|...|Everyone is so picky these days.
There's a pipe up there...|I pressed my ear against the warm opening...|...and I can hear... gurgling.|Shhh...!|...let's not wake it up.|There's no way to know what might come out.
The fiery fluid flickers with possibilities.|I wonder what happens...|...if you get a little closer?
Hello?|Um... hello?|Everything just went black.|Um... ok, I guess Ill just wait here.
A Sip at the Sour Note
A distant observer looked as far as the telescope could see.
a tiny speck in the distance...
I don't think they're listening at all...
...time almost stands still for people on the train.
...time is speeding up for us down here!
...you have A VISITOR in the west...
It must have been a long journey...
Someone had been watching for a long time.
But it was nice to see them again.

I think you have too many balls?
Complete a level collecting more than 800 balls.
Complete all levels in 3 hours or less, in game time.
Use time bugs 100 times, cumulatively, throughout the game.

Suck the This Way Up item into a pipe.
Score one move under the OCD requirement in a Goolf level.
Throw a non-Goolf ball at the exit such that it is sucked up without first landing on a structure - but the exit must be offscreen.
Destroy more than 120 balls in a level.
Build a tower at least 16 units tall.
Build a structure with at least 140 balls.
On the world map, launch a Goo Ball into outer space.
Wake up a Goo Ball by bumping it with another one.
Throw a non-Goolf ball at the exit such that it is sucked up without first landing on a structure.

This pipe has some sort of a filter attached...|It seems to indicate...|...it will accept ONLY processed Goo Balls.|Those freeloading ones that don't even try to build to the pipe.|It seems it will be difficult to get those up here.

World of Goo Corporation has specific aims for doing their Goo collection operations in this region.|They're wanting to collect only PRODUCT Goo Balls.|They're wanting some generic goo for Research and Development for new products.|So get to it.

World of Goo Organization has specific aims for collecting Goo here.|They're wanting to collect only PRODUCT Goo Balls.|Limiting the types of Goo Balls that are collected improves sustainability.|Capable Goo Balls are still in the environment.
